content:
Hello @T-compiler/meeting; triage meeting will take place in about 2h
WG-prioritization has done pre-triage in #t-compiler/wg-prioritization/alerts and prepared the meeting agenda

Scheduled checkins (emitting mentions again, just in case):

  • WG-async-foundations by @nikomatsakis and @tmandry: anything to share?
  • WG-traits by @nikomatsakis and @Jack Huey: anything to share?
Hi @T-compiler/meeting , our weekly triage meeting is starting now. Add a :wave: to show you’re here! :)
my zulip is impossibly slow for some reason. I’m going to reset the App and hope that does something.
well lets see how this works

lets start off with ~5 minutes for

Announcements

• Reminder: if you see a PR/issue that seems like there might be legal implications due to copyright/IP/etc, please let the Core team know (or at least message pnkfelix or Wesley Wiser so we can pass it along).
(is it ok to put this reminder at every meeting, right?)
Yes I approve.
To put it simply, copyright is a known existing issue in the project
leadership is currently working through existing ... "debt" ... related to copyright issues
In fact, let me be blunt: Don't rely on precedent as the basis for your actions.
Don't assume that if you see some existing example of something that its okay to do it again
because the leaders might well be trying to get rid of the thing you're using as justification.
(or at least address it in some fashion)
there was something else I was going to say ...
Oh yes

• tomorrow @Wesley Wiser and I will be using the steering meeting slot for a general review of beta regressions/backports. At least, that's what the time is allocated for. Anyone who wants to join us can do so.
any other announcements from the participants?
MCPs/FCPs

• New MCPs (take a look, see if you like them!)
    • No new proposals this time.

• Old MCPs (not seconded, take a look)
    • "Accept pc in place of unknown and unknown in place of pc for x86_64 and i?86 targets" compiler-team#441 (last review activity: 7 months ago)
    • "Make -Z binary-dep-depinfo the default behavior" compiler-team#464 (last review activity: 4 months ago)
    • "Tier 3 target proposal: riscv64gc-linux-android (Android target for riscv64gc)" compiler-team#472 (last review activity: about 55 days ago)
    • "-Dwarnings to cover all warnings" compiler-team#473 (last review activity: about 55 days ago)
    • "Build-time execution sandboxing" compiler-team#475 (last review activity: about 38 days ago)
    • "Dealing with type/const ambiguities" compiler-team#480 (last review activity: about 13 days ago)

• Pending FCP requests (check your boxes!)
    • No pending FCP requests this time.
  • Things in FCP (make sure you're good with it)
    • No FCP requests this time.
  • Accepted MCPs
    • No new accepted proposals this time.

• Finalized FCPs (disposition merge)
    • "Tracking issue for #[cfg(target_has_atomic = ...)]" rust#32976
    • "Change location of where clause on GATs" rust#90076
    • "Stabilize -Z instrument-coverage as -C instrument-coverage" rust#90132
WG checkins
There's new pending FCP request here: https://github.com/rust-lang/rfcs/pull/3224#issuecomment-1028824028
For WG-async-foundations, they'll be having their sprint meeting later today
but @tmandry or @nikomatsakis , if either of you have anything to report here now, feel free.
(I attend those meetings, I should probably take ownership of copying over any relevant stuff here)

• WG-traits by @nikomatsakis and @Jack Huey (previous checkin)

    Still haven't published the retrospective blog post (Niko was going to write some paragraphs but hasn't gotten to it yet).

    Generic associated types
    - A few more bug fix PRs have landed; there a couple PRs waiting for Jack to update
    - GAT where clause position question (#90076) has been resolved by lang team: we will accept both positions, but deprecate where clauses before the equals
    - Would like to think about and consider the design of std APIs with GATs prior to stabilization
    - generic-associated-types-initiative#1 covers Iterator/LendingIterator split; would love thoughts on use cases
    - Where clause question was the final "blocking" issue for GATs
    - A few more issues to triage, a documentation writeup, and library design considerations are precursors to stabilization

    TAITs
    - Lazy TAIT PR is open by Oli: #92007
    - It's being coreviewed by Niko and @lcnr

    async fn in traits
    - @spastorino is working on some ast lowering refactoring that's a precursor to this

    negative impls in coherence
    - @spastorino has done some more work here in #93175
Regarding wg-async
I don't have anything major to report-- there is ongoing polish work as well as refactorings to support RPIT etc
(return-position impl-trait)
well, RPITIT :) RPIT in traits
repeat it RPITIT
okay, next up
Backport nominations
T-compiler beta / T-compiler stable

• "Add links to the reference and rust by example for asm! docs and lints" rust#92611
    • This PR adds links that where removed in rust#91728
    • @Amanieu authored the PR and nominated for beta-backport
    • PR approved by @Mara
I think its fair to say that I could/should have unilaterally approved this one. :)
beta backport approved.
next up

• "backport llvm fix for issue 91671." rust#93426
    • PR fixes P-high rust#91671, a crash on compiling on aarch64 + LTO enabled
    • PR authored by Felix, also nominated for stable backport
    • Approved by @Nikita Popov
to be clear: This is an outright segfault from LLVM itself that's being resolved. A real crash, not an ICE/assert fail/etc
its essentially cherry-picking this: https://github.com/llvm/llvm-project/commit/0d1308a7b77c9ed87386c22a728a6c97e2fb4887
(I'm including more context in preparation for the stable-backport discussion that will follow shortly)
hey! we labeled #93394 as beta-accepted in the libs-api meeting, but it might be good if the compiler team also takes a look at it. Esteban mentioned he wasn't sure about backporting it.
okay, thanks @Mara ; lets talk about that in a second
it seems like everyone is cool with beta backporting rust#93426
so lets mark that as beta-approved
and we'll discuss the stable-backport question in a bit
but first, lets take a look at the #93394 that @Mara brought up
oh yeah, this
(we were just talking about this in the lang team meeting)
it seems fine to me to backport. Actually prudent to reduce the number of ppl who could end up depending on it
"Don't allow {} to refer to implicit captures in format_args." #93394
println!("{a} {b} {} {} {c} {}", c = "c"); currently works by accident. this fixes that.
like... the change is good and we either backport or never merge it
side note: it is not merged yet!
well, isn't there a middle ground of warning-cycling the change?
as a future-incompat warning?

side note: it is not merged yet!

(there's an r=me note already.)

pnkfelix said:

as a future-incompat warning?

(I'm not pushing hard for that option. I just want to make sure I raise the question, and point out that its not quite as black/white as @oli made it out to be.)
was warning cycling discussed on the PR? Let me look

future-incompat warning is possible, but probably not worth it. maybe the crater run can give us a bit more confidence. but obviously a lot of code is not on crates.io, and printing stuff is probably more common in binaries (which are usually not on crates.io) rather than libraries
Seems like the lang-team is also of the opinion we should fix asap https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/issues/93378#issuecomment-1027172938
so that is indeed the heart of the issue: is a warning-cycle the right thing, in order to accommodate the hypothetical instances that lie outside of crater's domain
it seems unlikely that any production code relies on this bug, considering how new this implicit/captured arguments feature is
which release was it stabilized in?
backporting means it's fixed in 1.59
okay
I'm willing to take that risk then, if the crater run comes back clean
Any reason not to stable backport?
too much overhead for a new point release

Mara said:

too much overhead for a new point release

this response goes back into our ongoing issue
that we need to move away from waterfall model for stable-backport approvals
and instead treat them like a dialogue with the release team
(we can approve for back port without the dot release being done, it just means that if there's one this goes out as well)
i.e. we're not in this meeting supposed to decide if a point release is worth it

mark was in the libs-api meeting when we discussed this. so from his release-team perspective he said it'd not be worth it. also taking into account the work for users/distributors of rust to upgrade to a new point release, etc.
my reasoning: backporting to stable signals harder that this was indeed a bug that shouldn't have been added
In other words: If some other issue motivated a point release
then would we want this to be included in that?
oh right. yes
My current take then: We're agreed with T-libs on a beta backport approval.
(though maybe @Esteban Küber wants to argue for the other side?)
hup, I guess not. :)
I'm ok with it.
okay.
lets talk stable backports now
and since this ad hoc one wasn't on agenda, lets deal with it first
"Don't allow {} to refer to implicit captures in format_args." #93394
so, obviously its inherently a breaking change: that's the whole point. :)
but in terms of what its doing, it seems very low risk
right?
if we had fixed this before 1.58.1, i think it should've been included. so i feel the same about a potential 1.58.2, if that version happens for some good reason.
("low risk" in that we believe we understand the scope of what behavior it changes)
Okay. I think stable-backport approved for this as well. And we'll just try to maybe include a note that we're just saying that this should be included in a point release, but does not motivate one.
so, next up

• "backport llvm fix for issue 91671." rust#93426
    • previously mentioned PR, also nominated for stable backport
this is why I included so much context earlier
I wanted to provide as much info as I could
I myself am on the fence about stable backporting rust#93426
on the one hand, there is definitely a bug its fixing
I get scared with llvm changes tbh
but on the other hand, ... I guess I'm just vaguely concerned with how little I understand about the overall picture with that codebase
yes, exactly
the main reason why I even bring up a stable backport here
Does it affect any aarch64 platform or just aarch64-apple-darwin?
Its all aarch64
It originally arose on aarch64 linux
and I was happy to reproduce it on my M1
what I don't know is if it can arise outside of LTO
aarch64 linux is tier 1 so that raises the priority in my mind.
that is, if the problem was known to be observable without LTO, then I would push hard for a backport, i think
but right now, someone "in the know" can disable LTO to work around it
Have we done comms to tell people to not use lto for now?
I don't know if there's an easy way to disable LTO for just one family of targets in a Cargo.toml. Is there?)
Namely, how is John r. Andom in some company tm aware of the side step?
Indeed, this was a concern of mine as well

So the options, as I see them, are: 1. put heads in sand and hope this problem is so rare that its not worth scaring people over it, 2. send out general notice that LTO should not be trusted on aarch64 in certain versions of Rust and/or LLVM, or 3. stable accept this as a signal that we're doing our best...
I suppose I'm attaching too much value when I use phrases like"put heads in sand". I shouldn't do that

In general I think we have a pile of bugs with LTO and/or codegen-units that can arise -- e.g., the work to update UI tests to mostly run with CGU=1 iirc hit a bunch of tests that failed and had to be manually adjusted
(that is, the concern about unnecessarily scaring people over a problem that is very rare is actually entirely legitimate.)
I'm not convinced this one is special
@simulacrum I think I'd like to dig into what you just talked about. Not in this meeting
i.e. I'd like to maybe capture some rr traces of failing runs
maybe you and I can follow up about that.
I'm currently going with "lets not stable backport this." Its better to let it bake.
Sound good, everyone?

IMO we should either stable backport the fix because it's important to fix or we should let it ride the trains. This doesn't seem critical enough that we should try to warn people but then not also backport the fix? (If that makes sense)
@Wesley Wiser the difference to me is that we can undo a beta backport
and I do want this in the next release
i.e., the whole reason that this problem was attached to 1.57 was due to totally different thing, where cargo started passing along the LTO flag to rustdoc
Given that this is aarch64 specific, I'm not really convinced this is going to get a lot of testing in beta tbh.
and that led to some projects saying "we need to stick to 1.56.1 until that segfault from rustdoc in 1.57 is resolved."
its not about the beta testing
its about the nightly testing
and being able to learn from that whether to take it out of beta
Well, I'm fine with letting it ride the trans so :thumbs_up:
Another way to go here would be to leave it beta-nominated for another week
I just am pushing back against beta declining this week.
Okay.

I wonder if we can get some interested group to do beta testing for this. It'd be a shame if it has to wait 12 weeks because we lack infra. That's a separate question that we should address at some point.
Lets stable-decline
and leave beta-nomianted
I want to push through agenda
@Esteban Küber I suppose if we can find stakeholders who want to agree to beta test aarch64, then we could make a push to land it in beta sooner.
okay. moving on

• "riscv32i: __atomic_load_4 is referenced in libcompiler_builtins" rust#92897
    • Note: #92897 is an issue, not a PR
    • @Amanieu comments that this is fixed in beta by rust-lang/compiler-builtins@e0187f1
    • suggests if this warrants a backport on stable, too (see Zulip discussion)
/me just realized we burned much of this hour on beta regressions/backport after having said there's an hour dedicated to it tomorrow. :lol:
holy shit, bunnie
I know them (well, more of friend-of-friend situation)
rust-lang/compiler-builtins@e0187f1 seems pretty low risk
I assume we would treat this also as "approved to go in a point release, but does not motivate one", right?
lets stable-approve it
next up

T-rustdoc beta / T-rustdoc stable

  • No backport nominations for T-rustdoc this time.

PRs S-waiting-on-team

T-compiler

  • No PRs waiting on T-compiler
I'm going to skip the "Oldest PRs waiting for review" this week
(though I recommend you we all skim over that portion of the agenda)

Issues of Note

Short Summary

  • 1 T-compiler P-critical issues
    • 0 of those are unassigned
  • 69 T-compiler P-high issues
    • 47 of those are unassigned
  • 0 P-critical, 1 P-high, 0 P-medium, 1 P-low regression-from-stable-to-beta
  • 0 P-critical, 1 P-high, 1 P-medium, 0 P-low regression-from-stable-to-nightly
  • 0 P-critical, 44 P-high, 80 P-medium, 12 P-low regression-from-stable-to-stable

P-critical

T-compiler
• "Named format arguments introduce implicit positional arguments" rust#93378
(discussed above, yay)

• "rustdoc ICE: 'no entry found for key'" rust#93476
    • Assigned P-critical based on a similar issue (#)
    • Anyway, it should be fixed by rust#93539
okay this broke recently enough that no backport will be needed

T-rustdoc

  • No P-critical issues for T-rustdoc this time.
/me squints
should rust#93476 have been tagged with T-rustdoc ? I guess since it was with compiler internal stuff, its T-compiler, not T-rustdoc?
no time for questions like that, what am I doing here

P-high regressions

P-high beta regressions

  • "Some mixes of Rust with C/C++ are broken for arm64 mac and windows" rust#92885
okay this has a fix but its not beta nominated yet?
no, wait, a fix landed in beta?
I'm so confused now
I think the fix in beta is in #93523
okay. so this is resolved then
https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/93269 fixed this on master and I approved the revert directly for beta, yes
It can be closed

Unassigned P-high nightly regressions

  • No unassigned P-high nightly regressions this time.

Performance logs

2022-02-02 triage logs

This was a relatively quiet week with regressions and improvements relatively equally each other out. The big exception is with a somewhat large regression in rustdoc which was needed for a large and important architectural change. This could lead to users see somewhat slower doc build times with more memory used especially in projects with large crate dependency graphs.

Triage done by @rylev.
Revision range: c54dfee65126a0ac385d55389a316e89095a0713..1ea4851715893ee3f365a8ef09d47165e9a7864f

2 Regressions, 4 Improvements, 2 Mixed; 1 of them in rollups
35 comparisons made in total
29 Untriaged Pull Requests

Regressions

rustdoc: Pre-calculate traits that are in scope for doc links #88679

  • Average relevant regression: 5.4%
  • Largest regression in instruction counts: 9.1% on full builds of regression-31157 doc
  • All the regressions are localized to rustdoc and are quite substantial but exacerbated by an architectural issue which needs to be solved.
  • The regressions are well known and extensively discussed in the PR with the next steps being tracked in an issue.

Store def_id_to_hir_id as variant in hir_owner. #93373

  • Average relevant regression: 1.2%
  • Average relevant improvement: -0.3%
  • Largest regression in instruction counts: 5.5% on incr-unchanged builds of match-stress-enum check
  • This is the first commit (originally bundled with #93301) of a larger PR (#89278) which saw larger PR regressions than the two sub PRs combined.
  • A more detailed justification for this can be found here, but in general this allows for even more incremental compilation and is thus worth the small immediate compilation performance penalty.

Improvements

  • Fix the unsoundness in the early_otherwise_branch mir opt pass #91840
  • Only traverse attrs once while checking for coherence override attributes #93343
  • Rollup of 10 pull requests #93427
  • Disable drop range analysis #93284

Mixed

Store hir_id_to_def_id in OwnerInfo. #93301

  • Average relevant regression: 0.6%
  • Average relevant improvement: -0.5%
  • Largest improvement in instruction counts: -0.6% on full builds of unused-warnings check
  • Largest regression in instruction counts: 2.2% on incr-unchanged builds of match-stress-enum check
  • This is the first commit (originally bundled with #93373) of a larger PR (#89278) which saw larger PR regressions than the two sub PRs combined.

Create core::fmt::ArgumentV1 with generics instead of fn pointer #90891

  • Average relevant regression: 1.2%
  • Average relevant improvement: -1.2%
  • Largest improvement in instruction counts: -6.7% on full builds of tokio-webpush-simple opt
  • Largest regression in instruction counts: 2.1% on full builds of keccak check
  • The improvements outweigh the regressions considerably and this was considered a fine trade off.

Nominated Issues

T-compiler

• "no_mangle/used static is only present in output when in reachable module" rust#47384
    • Both lang and compiler teams nominated by @inquisitivecrystal, see relevant comments (here and here)
    • WG-prioritization discussion on Zulip
    • Various comments indicate users' confusion and differently reporting this as a bug or works as intended
hmm
I think lang needs to discuss this first
but I don't understand, I dont remember it coming up in the T-lang meeting this week
oh we probably just ran out of time
much like how our team just ran out of time in this meeting. :lol:

RFC

  • No nominated RFCs for T-compiler this time.
but we're actually done. Yay!
Thanks to everyone in @T-compiler/meeting for attending!
@Wesley Wiser , I'm guessing our meeting tomorrow will not be about beta-regressions/backports
since the list is essentially handled now, apart from the question about that LLVM backport
Yeah. Do we have another meeting scheduled next week? If not perhaps we should bump it until then?
bump the beta regression/backport meeting until next week?
Yeah
Looks like we have a planning meeting.
heh
@Wesley Wiser well, you and I have our private meeting
so maybe we'll just use the 10am slot for that, and let the team go on their way tomorrow? Sound good?}
I gotta go, y'all! :wave:
Sounds good, let's do that.

Draft for next weeks' agenda available at:
https://hackmd.io/KW_vTfxFS2Ci4aLcQlF0mA?view

Scheduled checkins from:

  • WG-diagnostics by @Esteban Küber and @oli
  • WG-rustc-dev-guide by @Santiago Pastorino and @Yuki Okushi
